noun.description: An act of changing physical location or position or of having this changed.
examples: a slight movement of the upper body
the principle of the free movement of goods between member states
movements in the underlying financial markets

noun.description: A group of people working together to advance their shared political, social, or artistic ideas.
A principal division of a longer musical work, self-sufficient in terms of key, tempo, and structure.
examples: the slow movement of his violin concerto

origin: Late Middle English: via Old French from medieval Latin movimentum, from Latin movere to move.
